name: North Carolina Newsline
title: Federal funding changes could push thousands into homelessness in North Carolina
description: Nearly 3,000 North Carolinians could lose housing under changes to the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development’s [HUD] competitive grant program for permanent housing, according to an estimate by the National Alliance to End Homelessness. The alliance and other advocates are bracing for HUD reforms that will dramatically change the way the federal g[...]
text:
Arts and crafts at Fifth Street Ministries in Statesville, N.C. (Courtesy photo)Nearly 3,000 North Carolinians could lose housing under changes to the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development’s [HUD] competitive grant program for permanent housing, according to an estimate by the National Alliance to End Homelessness.
The alliance and other advocates are bracing for HUD reforms that will dramatically change the way the federal government funds permanent housing assistance programs.
The changes could cost the state more than $24 million in funding for programs that house people experiencing homelessness, the organization told N.C. Newsline. Nationally, more than 170,000 people could be at risk of homelessness due to changes to the $3.9 billion grant program, the alliance said.
Marcy Thompson (Photo: National Alliance to End Homelessness)
“Without that funding, it means services are disrupted, if not stopped altogether,” said Marcy Thompson, the alliance’s vice president of programs and policy. “If they [service providers] can’t continue operating, landlords don’t get rent. It creates a lot of distrust within the community.”
Grant reapplication required
At issue are federal Continuum of Care (CoC) grants, which is the largest federal grant program specifically for assisting people experiencing homelessness. 
The competitive grants are awarded on a two-year cycle, but HUD has required a new competition one year into the funding cycle.
“What we know is, there was originally a two-year promise,” said Liz Carbone, project specialist with the North Carolina Coalition to End Homelessness. “That promise has been walked back.”  
Liz Carbone, N.C. Coalition to End Homelessness (Courtesy Photo)
Carbone said the new competition could delay funding until spring for some awardees, leaving nonprofits scrambling to fill funding gaps to pay rent.
“We know that conservatively, best case, we will not see awards in our state until the end of May,” Carbone said. “The funding delay alone is going to be so deeply painful for our state.”
Most communities do not have the resources on hand to fill funding gaps if there are significant delays in grant awards, Carbone said. “If communities feel the need to assume these programs and keep them going, which I think most communities will, that’s a cost to the local taxpayer.” 
Federal money for homeless programs is dispersed through 12 Continuums of Care in North Carolina. Most are focused on larger cities such as Asheville, Charlotte, Durham, Raleigh and Wilmington.

Program priorities reversed
The controversial program changes come as HUD breaks from the long-favored “Housing First” approach, which prioritizes providing immediate access to permanent housing without prerequisites. HUD is moving to a transitional housing approach that includes work and sobriety requirements.
HUD Secretary Scott Turner (File Photo)
“These long-overdue reforms will promote independence and ensure we are supporting means-tested approaches to carry out the President’s mandate, connect Americans with the help they need, and make our cities and towns beautiful and safe,” HUD Secretary Scott Turner said in a statement announcing the changes.
One of the HUD reforms caps the amount of funding that each Continuum of Care (CoC) can use for permanent housing at no more than 30% of CoC funding. Currently, 87% of CoC-funded projects are for permanent housing or rapid-rehousing.
A new scoring criteria penalizes nonprofits competing for federal grants if they are located in areas that don’t, for example, have public camping bans in place. A statewide bill in North Carolina to enact such a ban stalled in the state Senate but some local municipalities have such bans in place.  
In July, President Trump issued an executive order that directed the HUD secretary and other cabinet secretaries to “determine whether priority” for grants may be given to grantees in states and municipalities that actively enforce prohibitions on urban camping and loitering, open illicit drug use and urban squatting.
The policy changes also penalize nonprofits for promoting diversity, equity and inclusion (DEI) or “gender ideology extremism,” and for the alleged “misuse of and abuse of taxpayers dollars on illegal aliens.”
“Some of the things that HUD is essentially penalizing organizations and communities for are things that were required of them in the last administration,” said Marcy Thompson at the National Alliance to End Homelessness. “There’s no community, no organization that is not at risk of being impacted here.”
Twenty congressional Republicans have asked HUD Secretary Scott Turner to renew grants expiring in 2026 for an additional year.
“This extension is essential to prevent service disruptions for individuals and families experiencing homelessness, sustain continuity of care for vulnerable populations, and allow HUD adequate time to implement its next generation of homelessness policy reforms,” the Republicans said in a letter to Turner.
While none of North Carolina’s congressional Republicans signed the letter, Carbone said advocates have had “super productive conversations” with several GOP U.S. House members and Republican U.S. Sens. Ted Budd and Thom Tillis.  
“They see the impacts that this is going to have, not just in the cities, but in the rural communities, and what this is going to do to North Carolina’s ability to keep the most vulnerable people in our state housed,” Carbone said. 
“Regardless of your political affiliation … we all care about seniors, we all care about families with young kids and we all care about veterans,” Carbone said.
Impact on the ground
Tamara Roach, director of Fifth St. Ministries, Statesville, N.C. (Courtesy photo)
In Statesville, Tamara Roach, executive director of Fifth Street Ministries, is three months into her new job. Roach would like to spend time meeting with donors, reviewing programs and preparing Thanksgiving meals the nonprofit will provide on Thursday. 
But recent days have been hectic. Roach has been busy with paperwork to meet this past Monday’s deadline for “letters of intent” to apply for the new HUD grants. Formal applications are due Jan. 14, she said.  
Nonprofits were only given a week to respond, she said.     
“I don’t think that providers are panicking, but we are paying attention,” Roach said. “It’s a very quick turnaround.” 
She said it’s healthy that HUD has asked providers to rethink models, reexamine how they define a disability and to discuss which services are leading to long-term housing stability.
“It’s just that we’re not being given much time at all to think about this and pivot,” Roach said. “I think some decisions folks are going to make are not going to be popular, but people can’t keep doing what they’ve always been doing without other collaboration and without other partners stepping up.”
To illustrate how funding changes could impact her organization, Roach shared a story about a client who lived in her car for months. Under the current funding model, Fifth Street Ministries, placed her in rapid rehousing, signed her up for counseling, connected her to medication to treat a bipolar disorder and enrolled her in a job training program.
Today, the client is housed and stable, Roach said.
“Under the new criteria, she may no longer qualify for that pathway because her bipolar disorder is no longer considered a disability,” Roach said. “If something happens and she’s not supported, it’s not as if she’s going to disappear. She’s going to cycle back to living in cars and shelters.”

name: Arkansas Advocate
title: Optimism for lithium in Arkansas is running high, even as challenges for industry growth remain
description: The state of play for Arkansas’ young-yet-ambitious lithium industry has changed markedly compared to one year ago, even as questions remain about the impacts of low lithium prices on projects. Almost exactly a year after prospective producers were dealt a defeat by the Arkansas Oil and Gas Commission over proposed royalty payments, business executives and [[...]
text:
Gov. Sarah Huckabee Sanders was a keynote speaker at the 2025 Arkansas Lithium Innovation Summit, pictured here on Oct. 28, 2025. (Photo by Ainsley Platt/Arkansas Advocate)The state of play for Arkansas’ young-yet-ambitious lithium industry has changed markedly compared to one year ago, even as questions remain about the impacts of low lithium prices on projects.
Almost exactly a year after prospective producers were dealt a defeat by the Arkansas Oil and Gas Commission over proposed royalty payments, business executives and lawmakers extolled the potential of the state’s lithium industry at the 2025 edition of the Arkansas Lithium Innovation Summit last month. Speakers from Google, Standard Lithium, Chevron, Fastmarkets and more spoke of how Arkansas’ lithium reserves could play into national security objectives, data centers for artificial intelligence and the clean energy transition.
Policymakers like Arkansas Secretary of Commerce Hugh McDonald touted Arkansas’ long history with the oil and gas industry and business-friendly climate to position the state as a future national leader in the “energy storage value chain.”
 
Read more about the big players in Arkansas’ lithium industry, and the events leading up to the first lithium royalty approval, here.


“When we met in February 2024, we spoke of promise. Now, in October 2025, we speak of progress. Extraordinary progress has been made in Arkansas the last 18 months,” McDonald said during remarks at the start of the summit. “We have a world-class resource in the Smackover Formation. … We aspire to become the most reliable, economic and sustainable domestic lithium resource.”
Extracting Arkansas’ underground lithium could be game changing for the U.S. as a whole as it tries to break its reliance on China and other foreign countries for the critical mineral that powers everything from smartphones to electric vehicles. A U.S. Geological Survey study found last year that Southwest Arkansas alone could produce enough lithium to supply the entirety of the world’s demand for car batteries in 2030 nine times over — though that study didn’t examine whether it was possible to extract all of it.
Lithium is found in the Smackover Formation’s salty brines, thousands of feet below the earth’s surface. Companies like ExxonMobil and Standard Lithium aim to extract it using commercially untested direct lithium extraction technology, which is similar to water softening. The formation stretches from East Texas to the western side of the Florida Panhandle, and the section underlying South Arkansas has long been associated with the Natural State’s oil and gas industry.
The summit came after a year and a half of back-and-forth between the state’s oil and gas regulator and prospective lithium producers over fair and equitable royalties for south Arkansas mineral rights owners. The Oil and Gas Commission approved royalty payment structures for two companies this year, clearing what has been referred to as the final undetermined regulatory hurdle.
The royalties aside, big names in Arkansas’ lithium space said they made strides in 2025. Canada-based Standard Lithium and Equinor, a Norwegian energy company, released a string of positive news about the feasibility of its Smackover Lithium project. The two companies have pointed to $225 million in U.S. Department of Energy funding and its designation as a priority critical mineral project by the Trump administration as evidence of the project’s strengths. Executives with the companies said on multiple occasions that they would make a decision about giving the final go-ahead for the project by early 2026.
Meanwhile, Chevron joined fellow American petroleum giants ExxonMobil and Occidental Petroleum in snapping up mineral rights in the state’s southwest region.
Shane Khoury, secretary of the Arkansas Department of Energy and Environment, told the Advocate in an interview at the summit that figuring out the royalty had been a long process, but that future lithium royalties would be able to rely on its precedent.
“I think [the royalty-setting process] was a little bit longer than we probably all anticipated,” Khoury said, in part because the state “didn’t have anybody to turn to and look at and say, ‘How do we value this process?’”
The state’s existing regulatory framework for brine extraction guided the process, Khoury said. Companies have been extracting bromine from brine in South Arkansas since the 1960s. The structure of the two approved royalties provides both a framework for other Arkansas lithium projects and for lithium projects in other states, he said.
“We kind of had to invent the wheel to start,” Khoury said. “They don’t have to reinvent the wheel.”
Still, much of the optimism at the summit was cautious. While remaining positive overall about the trajectory of the U.S. lithium industry over the few decades, multiple business leaders warned of how lithium prices, down from a massive pandemic-era spike thanks to supply outstripping demand, could negatively affect the U.S. industry’s attempts to get off the ground should they not increase. And closer to home, local community leaders from South Arkansas and executives from utility companies said that the region would be facing growing demands for power, housing and other resources that will likely need to be built out rapidly as the industry grows.
First-of-its-kind lithium technology accelerator kicks off in Arkansas

“The lithium industry, much like a lot of the new industries coming to Arkansas, are big power consumers,” Entergy Arkansas Vice President of Business Operations and Strategy Kristen Dalrymple said during a panel on infrastructure.
Arkansas’ transmission capacity is nearing its limits, which likely means there will be a large expansion of power transmission in the state in the coming years, Dalrymple said.
Nonprofit electric grid manager, Little Rock-based Southwest Power Pool, approved an $8.6 billion plan in November to upgrade and expand transmission grid capabilities across 14 states, Arkansas Business reported.
The need for more electricity and expanded transmission lines is especially true in the rural South Arkansas areas where lithium companies are locating, Dalrymple said. Striking a balance between attracting business and maintaining affordability is important, especially at a time where demand for power and grid upgrades is growing nationally as well, which impacts cost and timelines, she said.
“I’ll just say that it is unprecedented levels of growth we were talking about,” Dalrymple said. “So it’s an exciting time, but it’s a challenge in terms of making sure that we’re planning ahead, but also not overcommitting. So we need to strike that right balance.”
For its part, Entergy is seeking regulatory approval to build a $1.6 billion gas-fueled power plant near Redfield to take up some of the energy generating slack when it retires two coal-fired plants, one in 2028 and another in 2030, Arkansas Business reported.
Despite the challenges, policymakers remain optimistic.
“The lithium boom requires everything from skilled engineers to updated power grids and new housing and finally, state and federal policies that enable end-to-end development of the nation’s lithium supply chain,” McDonald said. “We can’t be all things to all sections of the supply chain, so, for now, we want to focus our strategy and lean into our natural advantages in building an industrial ecosystem.”
Republican Sen. Steve Crowell of Magnolia told the Advocate that while hurdles, such as power infrastructure and overcoming skepticism from financial backers beyond Arkansas, remain for the industry, “we’re moving in the right direction.”
Crowell said that 18 months previously there were still lots of unknowns about the lithium extraction projects.
“Now, as you’re seeing, there’s lots of facts, there’s lots of stats, there’s lots of things that are going down,” he said.
Local, state and federal leadership have been aligned in a way he called “an anomaly” to help the lithium industry succeed. Crowell said he would be shocked if there weren’t more large leaps by the industry in 2026.
“So that is a million dollar question: Where are we going to be a year from now?” Crowell said. “As I see it, it’s only a trajectory of up.”

name: Tennessee Lookout
title: Library groups, publishers criticize Tennessee secretary of state’s gender identity audit
description: Book publishers and literary groups are challenging orders by Tennessee’s secretary of state for public libraries to audit children’s collections and eliminate books dealing with gender identity. Groups such as the American Library Association, Penguin Random House, the National Coalition Against Censorship and Lambda Literary were joined this week by PEN Am[...]
text:
Some libraries have shut down to conduct an audit of "age-appropriate" books as required by Tennessee Secretary of State Tre Hargett.(Max McCoy/Kansas Reflector)Book publishers and literary groups are challenging orders by Tennessee’s secretary of state for public libraries to audit children’s collections and eliminate books dealing with gender identity.
Groups such as the American Library Association, Penguin Random House, the National Coalition Against Censorship and Lambda Literary were joined this week by PEN America, a nonprofit organization that advocates for free speech by defending literature and human rights, in denouncing directives by Secretary of State Tre Hargett. He is requiring libraries that receive state or federal grant funds to make an “age-appropriate” review of books and meet an order by President Donald Trump called “Defending Women from Gender Ideology Extremism and Restoring Biological Truth to the Federal Government.”
The order has required some libraries to shut down temporarily, according to a WTVF report, and go through the expensive task of poring over books to determine whether they contain gender identity topics.
Tennessee Secretary of State Tre Hargett has ordered an audit of libraries receiving state or federal grant funds. (Photo: John Partipilo/Tennessee Lookout)
More than 30 organizations nationally signed on to a letter expressing “profound concern” about Hargett’s September and October letters issued within the Tennessee Regional Library System demanding a full review within 60 days. In addition to creating “widespread confusion, fear and operational disruption” in libraries statewide, the order put a costly burden on libraries and created the risk of illegal censorship, the letter says.
“It is illegal to remove books from public libraries because some people do not like them. This is a well-settled legal principle,” the letter says. It adds that reviews for removal based on a person’s “subjective opinion” threaten First Amendment rights.
The letter also says the executive order, which regulates only federal agencies, is not legislation and points out that Congress opted not to pursue such a bill.
Hargett’s Sept. 8 letter to the Library Regional System ordering the reviews says Trump’s executive order prevents federal funds from being used to promote gender ideology, which “replaces the biological category of sex with an ever-shifting concept of self-assessed gender identity.”
The secretary of state also makes note of a new state law, Dismantling DEI Departments Act, that “prevents governmental entities from using discriminatory preferences to promote diversity, equity, or inclusion.” He encourages libraries with questions about grant contracts or federal and state laws to contact their county attorney.
Final reports by regional libraries are to be made by Jan. 19, 2026 to the Tennessee State Librarian and Archivist.
Hargett’s office didn’t return a call Wednesday seeking comment.

name: North Dakota Monitor
title: Pipeline developer asking North Dakota Supreme Court to weigh in on foreign Greenpeace case
description: The developer of the Dakota Access Pipeline is appealing a North Dakota’s judge’s decision not to interfere in a free speech lawsuit Greenpeace filed against the company overseas. The Amsterdam-based Greenpeace International filed the case in February in response to Energy Transfer’s lawsuit accusing it of engaging in acts including conspiracy and defamation[...]
text:
Flags from tribal nations are displayed near Cannonball, N.D., in August 2016 in solidarity with the Standing Rock Sioux Tribe in opposition to the Dakota Access Pipeline. (Kyle Martin/For the North Dakota Monitor)The developer of the Dakota Access Pipeline is appealing a North Dakota’s judge’s decision not to interfere in a free speech lawsuit Greenpeace filed against the company overseas.
The Amsterdam-based Greenpeace International filed the case in February in response to Energy Transfer’s lawsuit accusing it of engaging in acts including conspiracy and defamation to stop the Dakota Access Pipeline from being built. 
That lawsuit, which is ongoing in North Dakota district court, is also against two other Greenpeace entities: Greenpeace USA and Greenpeace Fund. In March, a Morton County jury handed down a more than $660 million verdict against Greenpeace, which the court later slashed by roughly half.
Greenpeace International’s counter-suit in the Netherlands alleges that Energy Transfer’s legal challenge is a ploy to waste its time and money. The Dutch case also claims Energy Transfer is liable for making defamatory statements about the environmental group. Greenpeace International has asked the court to order Energy Transfer to award it monetary damages.
Energy Transfer this summer asked Southwest District Court Judge James Gion to suspend the overseas lawsuit until the North Dakota case plays out — a request he rejected in September. 
Gion found that the cases consider different legal claims, so he didn’t think it necessary to stop the foreign action. Gion also stated he didn’t believe the Netherlands case would move quickly enough to affect the lawsuit in his court.
Now Energy Transfer wants the North Dakota Supreme Court to step in and order Gion to pause the Dutch lawsuit. The high court is set to hear arguments on the appeal on Dec. 18. 
In its petition to the Supreme Court, Energy Transfer claims the Dutch case “collaterally attacks the jury verdict” and is an attempt to sidestep North Dakota’s legal system.
“This Court’s intervention is needed to prevent a foreign entity (Greenpeace) from inviting a foreign tribunal to sit in judgment over North Dakota’s judiciary,” Energy Transfer wrote.
While Energy Transfer acknowledges no North Dakota court has ever attempted to pause a case in another country, they say it’s necessary in order to preserve the integrity of the North Dakota suit.
Judge slashes jury damages in Greenpeace case to $345 million

Greenpeace International has indicated it will participate in oral arguments before the high court in support of Gion’s decision. In legal documents, the organization said Energy Transfer has no basis for involving it in the North Dakota suit in the first place. It said it never had any staff visit North Dakota during the Dakota Access Pipeline protests, and that it only ever peripherally supported activism against the pipeline.
“International is a Netherlands entity with no connection to North Dakota,” it wrote. “It has thus consistently objected to Plaintiffs’ contentions that it could be haled into this jurisdiction to defend itself.”
Greenpeace was one of many activist groups that backed a movement led by the Standing Rock Sioux Tribe to halt construction of the Dakota Access Pipeline, which drew thousands of activists to protest in south-central North Dakota in 2016 and 2017.
The pipeline, often referred to as DAPL, carries crude oil from wells in northwest North Dakota to Illinois and has been in operation since 2017.
SUPPORT: YOU MAKE OUR WORK POSSIBLE
The state of North Dakota filed a friend-of-the-court brief in Energy Transfer’s appeal in support of neither party. 
The Supreme Court should use the case as an opportunity to develop guidelines on how North Dakota courts should handle requests to halt foreign lawsuits in the future, the state argued.
“In our current era of increasing political polarization, cross-jurisdictional legal tensions are likely to recur as polities continue to be increasingly aggressive in adopting divergent laws,” it wrote.
According to the state’s brief, orders to pause overseas lawsuits are generally warranted when the foreign case is substantially similar to a domestic lawsuit, and when the foreign action could impede the United States’ ability to enforce its own laws.
Greenpeace International’s lawsuit was filed under a 2024 European Union directive meant to protect activists and whistleblowers who face arbitrary legal action for exercising their free speech rights.
Greenpeace International has said its case may be the first to be filed under the new law.
The state of North Dakota in its brief appeared critical of the directive, writing that it “may have been purposefully enacted to facilitate the filing of lawsuits to collaterally challenge or undermine judicial proceedings that occur in third countries.”
Gion has yet to enter a final judgment in the North Dakota lawsuit. Earlier this month, he cut the jury’s more than $660 million verdict against Greenpeace to about $345 million.
Greenpeace has indicated previously that once Gion enters a judgment, it will ask for a new trial. If that request is unsuccessful, they will appeal the case to the North Dakota Supreme Court.
North Dakota Monitor reporter Mary Steurer can be reached at msteurer@northdakotamonitor.com.

name: North Carolina Newsline
title: Medicaid: Facts and Concerns
description: In 1965, after creating Medicare to provide health services for people over the age of 65, the federal government created Medicaid to help low-income children and disabled people of all ages access necessary health and human services. Medicare is funded and administered at the federal level. Medicaid is a joint venture through which a state […]
text:
A sign displayed by U.S. Senate Democrats at a Washington, DC press conference on Feb. 19, 2025. (Photo by Shauneen Miranda/States Newsroom)In 1965, after creating Medicare to provide health services for people over the age of 65, the federal government created Medicaid to help low-income children and disabled people of all ages access necessary health and human services. Medicare is funded and administered at the federal level. Medicaid is a joint venture through which a state receives most funding from the federal government but must pay a percentage based on the economic health of the state. In North Carolina, our federal Medicaid matching percentage is 68%. The state covers 32% of the cost. 
States administer Medicaid and set provider and hospital payment; these payment rates cannot exceed 100% of the Medicare rates. In 1989, Congress passed the Omnibus Budget Reduction Act (OBRA 89) which said that Medicaid payment should be sufficient for providers to afford to accept Medicaid patients just as they would patients who have private insurance. Providers have sued state governments because of inadequate Medicaid payment with little success, even though OBRA 89 says that adequate Medicaid payment is the responsibility of the states. 
North Carolina does not currently pay anywhere near the Medicare rates for Medicaid services, and Medicaid fees for providers have not kept up with the increasing cost of living in our economy for a number of years. The only way doctors and hospitals can participate in Medicaid is to generate revenue from patients who have private insurance, since private sector payments average about 130% of the Medicare rates.
In our state, we have seen the the percentage of children covered by Medicaid increase over the past few decades, meaning that it has become increasingly difficult for doctors and hospitals to cover their practice costs like staff salaries and supplies. In particular, rural family physicians, obstetricians, dentists, eye doctors, and pediatricians will be the health professionals who will most likely be forced to turn patients away when these Medicaid cuts reduce cash flow to the breaking point for practice survival. 
Personally, as a pediatrician who has developed a large multi-county “safety net” practice in eastern NC, I worry that we will have to limit our participation in Medicaid and force many of our 25,000+ Medicaid patients to seek care elsewhere – and there are very few options for these children in rural North Carolina.
I hope our General Assembly and Governor Stein understand the seriousness of these new Medicaid cuts for the at-risk low-income children in our state!
David Tayloe, Jr., MD, FAAP
Dr. David Tayloe is a pediatrician in Goldsboro, N.C.

name: Louisiana Illuminator
title: After a father’s immigration arrest, this family decided to go back to Honduras
description: NEW ORLEANS – Lucia Lopez was leaving St. Alphonsus Parish — her 3-year-old daughter in tow — after participating in the Eucharist adoration on Oct. 30 when her brother-in-law called. Federal immigration agents had arrested her husband, Orlin Lopez Fuentes, he told her. “I didn’t believe it,” Lucia said in an interview at the church […]
text:
Lucia Lopez holds up a photo of her husband, Orlin Lopez Fuentes, as she sits with her daughters Camila, 6, and Angeles, 3, and their dog Nuno at their home in Harvey on Nov. 24, 2025. After living in the U.S. for six years, they plan to return to Honduras later this week. (Photo by Christiana Botic/Verite News and Catchlight Local/Report for America)NEW ORLEANS – Lucia Lopez was leaving St. Alphonsus Parish — her 3-year-old daughter in tow — after participating in the Eucharist adoration on Oct. 30 when her brother-in-law called. Federal immigration agents had arrested her husband, Orlin Lopez Fuentes, he told her.
“I didn’t believe it,” Lucia said in an interview at the church two weeks after he was detained. “I was in shock.”
Orlin, a welder, had been at work at a shipyard in Harvey when U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement conducted a large-scale raid capturing dozens of workers — all Honduran citizens.
A press release from U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement, published days after the arrests, quoted Deputy Special Agent In Charge Matt Wright from the agency’s local Homeland Security Investigations unit, based in New Orleans.
“This operation demonstrates our commitment to enforcing immigration laws and holding employers accountable,” Wright said.
However, the press release did not mention any penalties levied against Orlin’s employer, aside from the loss of laborers.
For Orlin, the greatest penalty was spending a month separated from Lucia and their two daughters Camila, 6, and Angeles, 3, he said in a phone interview Tuesday with Verite News.
Lucia Lopez holds a family photo from Christmas of 2023 with her husband Orlin Lopez Fuentes and their daughters Angeles and Camila. (Photo by Christiana Botic/Verite News and Catchlight Local/Report for America)
“When I was arrested the first thing I thought [of] was my wife and my daughters. We had always been together,” Orlin said. “One of the most painful things you can put a person through is separating them from their family.”
Orlin is one of thousands of people in Louisiana caught in the Trump administration’s immigration enforcement dragnet that, despite its stated goals to prioritize the arrests and deportations of violent criminals, has indiscriminately impacted immigrant families, separating parents from children and splitting spouses apart.
Now, as the New Orleans metro area and the rest of Louisiana brace for the incursion of hundreds of U.S. Border Patrol agents who intend to sweep the region with immigration arrests similar to those seen in Illinois and North Carolina, Orlin, Lucia and their girls are planning to start their lives over in Honduras, where they can be together without fear of being ripped apart again.
Orlin was deported to Honduras on Nov. 22, ICE verified. Lucia said she and their children will soon join him there.
Friends at St. Alphonsus Parish called Orlin, a choir director at the church, a strong leader, who spoke up for Spanish speaking congregants and helped other men strengthen their relationships with God and their families.
SUBSCRIBE: GET THE MORNING HEADLINES DELIVERED TO YOUR INBOX
Immigration attorney and fellow parishioner Marco Balducci said he felt compelled to help Orlin and his family navigate the immigration legal system. Their wish was “modest,” he said. Orlin hoped he would be released under ICE’s supervision so that they could tie up whatever loose ends they had and return to Honduras together within a few months. They had quickly come to terms with having to leave the U.S. and just wanted to do it as a family, on a normal, commercial flight.
Balducci said he’d try to make what they wished for a reality, but it wasn’t likely. He thought the way Orlin, who has no criminal record, was arrested and detained was not fair.
“Orlin is not somebody who deserves this,” Balducci said. “Given the violence and the force that’s being used both in the apprehension and the detention of people, this is an inappropriate method of immigration enforcement.”
Orlin said he was detained for nearly three weeks at Pine Prairie ICE Processing Center, a privately run detention facility in Evangeline Parish that, according to immigration data researchers calculations, has been operating well above its contractual capacity of 500 detainees for most of 2025. He shared a room that had four bunk beds with 13 other people – eight men slept in the beds. The other six or so, including Orlin, slept on mattresses on the floor, Orlin said. He was given an orange uniform, more than a week into his detention, he said. Before that, he had been wearing the clothes he was arrested in. He said he never received an extra change of clothes, including underwear, confirming what other recent detainees at the facility have reported. He would shower and then put the same clothes back on. Maybe that, he wondered, was why he broke out in rashes. Or maybe it was the blankets; they were made of a “weird” material, he said. Or maybe it was the tap water, which had a taste that Orlin likened to dirty toilet water.
Verite News contacted ICE for comment on the circumstances of Orlin’s detention and conditions at Pine Prarie, but the agency did not respond in time for publication.
Christopher Ferreira, director of corporate relations at Geo Group, the private prison corporation that owns and operates Pine Prairie said the company “rejects these allegations, which are meant to criticize the quality of our services,” in an emailed statement.
Ferreira said Pine Prairie issues all detainees two uniforms, two pairs of underwear, two pairs of socks and one pair of shoes at intake, adding that the company follows ICE’s detention standards.


Let us know what you think...


 


Orlin requested voluntary departure — a request to leave within a set time frame and at his own expense — which an immigration judge granted. But he wasn’t released. Balducci explained that the grant from the judge acknowledges that he’d chosen to close his case and leave on his own. It didn’t mean he would actually be released. Instead of leaving with his family, Orlin said, he was deported in handcuffs and shackles, with chains hanging from his chest and waist, for 10 hours, including the flight from Alexandria International Airport (in Central Louisiana) to Honduras.
“I think it was one of the worst experiences for me because I have never lived through being treated like that,” Orlin said. “They treated us like we were criminals and we really were just people who had a dream.”
Orlin said their dream was to make sure Camila lived. According to Lucia, Camila was only 52 days old when she and Orlin carried her across Mexico’s border with Texas. Lucia had given birth to two daughters before Camila, but they’d both died — one as a toddler and the other as an infant — of respiratory complications that the couple associated with air pollution from the cement factory in their town, Piedras Azules , where Orlin worked. They’d taken the second child to Tegucigalpa, the capital of Honduras, for specialized care. When she died, they lost faith in Honduras’ healthcare system.
Lucia said they would never have come to the United States if she hadn’t had Camila. But once she was born, they couldn’t imagine enduring the death of another child.

Since Orlin’s arrest, Camila has suffered from anxiety. She had to be picked up from school one day after a teacher called because she would not stop crying, Lucia said.
“She’s worried that the same thing that happened to her dad is gonna happen to me,” Lucia said in a phone interview on Tuesday. “She’s really traumatized by immigration. She doesn’t ever want to be alone.”
Now, Camila prays for the family to leave their home in Harvey, where, in anticipation of the upcoming Border Patrol sweeps, drones have been spotted hovering over the neighborhood, Lucia said. Her prayers will be answered by the end of the week.
Camila Lopez, 6, holds up a note that her classmates gave her after they learned she was moving back to Honduras. (Photo by Christiana Botic/Verite News and Catchlight Local/Report for America)
Lucia has mixed feelings about returning home after six years. She’s happy her daughters will get to know life in Honduras, but she worries about difficulties with finding work and transportation there. And while she’ll be reunited with her mother and a sibling in Honduras, her daughters are being separated from their cousins here in the U.S.
Orlin’s work as a welder allowed them to save enough money to buy a house in Honduras. Lucia said she’s looking forward to making it a home. Orlin is hopeful that the family can “have peace” there.
Orlin said starting a new life back home can be “something beautiful.” He shared a parting message for other Hispanic immigrants “that want to keep trying for their dream in the U.S.”
“What I lived through is something that I wouldn’t wish on anyone,” he said. “Take care of yourselves, be careful, try to protect yourselves because things are getting pretty bad.”
This article first appeared on Verite News New Orleans and is republished here under a Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivatives 4.0 International License.

name: Colorado Newsline
title: ​Affordable housing development boost sought with new Colorado online portal
description: A new online portal run by the state intends to streamline the process for developers applying for affordable housing funding and tax credits in Colorado.  Housing Hub Colorado — a collaboration between several state agencies, the Colorado Housing and Finance Authority, and Denver’s Department of Housing Stability — aligns application timelines and informati[...]
text:
Colorado Gov. Jared Polis speaks at a ribbon cutting ceremony unveiling 12 workforce housing units for corrections workers Aug. 9, 2024, in Buena Vista. (Photo courtesy of the governor's office)A new online portal run by the state intends to streamline the process for developers applying for affordable housing funding and tax credits in Colorado. 
Housing Hub Colorado — a collaboration between several state agencies, the Colorado Housing and Finance Authority, and Denver’s Department of Housing Stability — aligns application timelines and information for different entities that offer funding to developers building affordable rental housing. 
“Colorado is breaking down barriers to more housing people can afford and this one-stop shop will help make that possible in more communities across our state,” Colorado Gov. Jared Polis, a Democrat, said in a statement. “This effort will save people, and local communities, time and money when building new homes in Colorado.”
SUBSCRIBE: GET THE MORNING HEADLINES DELIVERED TO YOUR INBOX
State agencies supporting the project include the Department of Local Affairs and the Office of Economic Development and International Trade. Funding sources for affordable housing come from the state’s local affairs department and Denver’s housing stability department.
“A strong economy depends on good-paying jobs and housing Coloradans can afford,” Eve Lieberman, executive director of the economic development office, said in a statement. “By simplifying the process of applying for funding, we are reducing time and cost burdens for communities and developers and accelerating the creation of homes near jobs and industry.”










Colorado is breaking down barriers to more housing people can afford and this one-stop shop will help make that possible in more communities across our state.


– Colorado Gov. Jared Polis


The Housing Hub is the first initiative to come from the Colorado Housing Consortium, a collaboration between over 100 entities in the private and public sectors looking to accelerate more affordable housing development in the state. 
A survey of those who applied for affordable housing tax credits in the last two years found that 85% of respondents wanted to see a statewide application to improve the process of applying for funding, according to a press release from Polis’ office. Applying through multiple funding sources dragged on build timelines and put affording housing projects at risk, according to 65% of survey respondents.  
“There is no greater need in Denver and Colorado than affordable housing, and no greater obstacle to our success than time,” Denver Mayor Mike Johnston said in a statement.
A second phase of the project will include a common application accepted by all agencies.
Polis has made “More Housing Now” a key goal throughout his second term as governor. Demographers estimate Colorado needs about 100,000 more units to meet the housing demand in the state.

name: West Virginia Watch
title: One West Virginia native is working to change the state’s narrative, one act of kindness at a time
description: Parkersburg, West Virginia native, Reed Byers, believes that a small gesture, offered at the right moment, can cut through the kind of loneliness many people carry but often struggle to name. In West Virginia, where isolation is common and connection frequently feels like something one must earn, he learned early what it meant to grow […]
text:
Reed Byers brings his #1BillionHugs movement into communities across West Virginia, meeting people where they are and offering a moment of connection without condition. (Courtesy photo)Parkersburg, West Virginia native, Reed Byers, believes that a small gesture, offered at the right moment, can cut through the kind of loneliness many people carry but often struggle to name. In West Virginia, where isolation is common and connection frequently feels like something one must earn, he learned early what it meant to grow up without the safety nets other places take for granted. So when a stranger wrapped him in a hug one morning at a Tudor’s Biscuit World in Huntington — no questions, no judgment — it landed with a force he couldn’t shake.
That moment didn’t solve anything outright, but it reframed something for Byers. After years of addiction, loss and rebuilding, he’d been carrying the quiet weight familiar to so many Americans, and particularly Appalachians, who navigate their hardest days alone. The simple act of someone pulling him in — just long enough to feel seen — became the seed of an idea he couldn’t ignore.
Today, that idea has taken shape as #1BillionHugs, a community-rooted effort built around human contact, mental health and the kind of everyday grace that rarely makes headlines. What started as a T-shirt with a catchy slogan has begun to spread across the state and beyond, carried by people who understand the power of a gesture that asks for nothing in return. And in a region where the struggle can be both connection and the chance to build a life that feels possible, Byers is betting that something as small and unguarded as a hug might change the way people feel about themselves, their neighbors, and the place they call home.

Full circles being what they are, Byers’ life didn’t follow a straight line. Born in Marietta, Ohio, he spent his early childhood in Parkersburg, where his father worked at a plant and his mother earned a nursing degree. 
“Before 13, I had a pretty decent childhood,” he said. “Yes, there was domestic violence and drug use, but when they were present, when they weren’t consumed with that, they were pretty good parents. I was involved in rec sports and extracurriculars and academic stuff, and I had clothes on my back.”
Everything shifted when the family broke apart. A volatile divorce sent him to North Carolina for several years — deepening the instability. His mother left the family for a drug dealer, falling deeper into addiction, and his father didn’t know how to cope. 
“Next thing you know, my brother’s 17 and catching a felony for trafficking weed. And here I am, watching all this happen at 13.”
Byers was the last in his immediate family to start using drugs — at 13. 
“It was sort of part of our family culture,” he said. 
He returned to West Virginia during high school, moving to St. Marys with his father. They smoked marijuana together until Byers realized he needed something different.
“I wanted to go to college. I was in youth leadership programs. I was on an academic team, a science bowl team. I really wanted to make a difference — pursue academic endeavors — but my lifestyle, family life, wasn’t really conducive to that.”
So Byers staged his own intervention — moving out, living with an aunt and finally landing in a small community outreach apartment where staff let him stay if he promised to attend school. 
“Which I did,” he said. “I was the first immediate sibling to graduate high school.” 
After graduation, he tried to cling to the few positive influences in his life, working briefly at Camp Horseshoe, where he’d seen a glimpse of structure and purpose.
College came next — West Virginia Wesleyan — though it didn’t last. Dropping out left him adrift. 
“I fell into the bar scene, eventually getting diagnosed with a mental illness, ending up homeless,” he said. “This pattern continued over the next four years in my early 20s — homelessness, mental illness, onset drug use.” 

The spiral deepened until, at 24, he was arrested in Ohio. 
“You go from smoking weed at 13 to trafficking meth at 24”
Byers uses his story to help audiences rethink what resilience can look like — and how community can carry people through their hardest seasons. (Courtesy photo)
Called to create
Prison became the hard stop he never saw coming. And yet, even there, someone showed up for him.
“The only person that came and visited me at Noble Correctional Institution was my mentor, David King — the director of Camp Horseshoe in the Youth Leadership Association,” Byers said — noting that King had believed in him long before he believed in himself. “He used to drop off canned goods and books on the porch of the boarding house when I was in high school. This guy genuinely believed in me, saw potential in me. He came to my graduation and gave me “The Purpose Driven Life.”
In prison, King pushed Byers to see possibility. 
“He saw something in me that I didn’t see. He said, no, you’ve got a purpose. You see what’s not working. You’ve witnessed people around you lose their lives, take their lives, give it away and you’ve chosen your health instead.” 
Together, they sketched out the framework that would anchor Byers’ return to the world: a four-page plan of action: mind, spirit, body, relationships.
Upon returning home in 2020, Byers felt something unfamiliar — clarity. 
“I thought, I’ve really put my health together. I’d lost 60 pounds. I’d started working out and running. What do I want to do with my life?” The answer arrived quickly. “I wanted to be helpful. That was the answer.”
Byers took a job as a youth peer supporter at Westbrook Health Services — the same agency where he’d once been a patient. However, while the work was meaningful, he discovered the system wasn’t built for someone like him.
“Organizationally, the systems that exist that we’ve created are not meeting all of the needs in the communities,” he said. “You hired me to make a difference because of my lived experience, but now my lived experience is becoming a barrier.” 

Byers wasn’t allowed into high schools or the Boys & Girls Club because of his background. 
“These kids are often the ones going home to the harshest environments — sometimes wanting to take their own lives. We were receiving grant money from the state to solve these problems, but you’re telling me no.”
And so he left, determined to build something outside the limits of existing structures. He created a youth recovery initiative called How to Save a Life, developed programming, built an advisory team, raised funds, and was close to a $50,000 pilot. But still, something felt misaligned. 
“Even working underneath an existing nonprofit wasn’t the best fit because I’m called to go and build my own thing. I can work well with people. I just think I’m called to create and not necessarily fit inside of a container.”
Byers pivoted again — this time into a new identity. 
“I ended up opening a business as a motivational speaker,” he said. “I’ve been operating that for over three years now — it’s been very successful.” 

He’s spoken to mental health organizations, high school assemblies, civic groups, health departments, universities and tens of thousands online. His message is simple and relentless: Recovery is possible. Yes, you can do it. Take care of your mind, spirit, body. And we are all responsible in our community for affecting the change that we believe in. Nobody’s coming to save us.
(Left) #1BillionHugs stickers carry the movement’s core message: step toward one another, even if just for a moment. (Right) At the heart of the endeavor, Byers considers each #1BillionHugs T-shirt a wearable signal of hope, carried into the world one person at a time. (Courtesy photos)
 More than a brand

At this point in his life, two things stand out most for Byers when thinking about West Virginia: the depth of its people and the limits of opportunity. 
“It doesn’t seem like there’s ever enough resources,” he said. 
In his attempts to crack the code, Byers has served on nonprofit boards, built volunteer movements, run for office, and eventually held a seat on the Cabell County Board of Education. 
“Our budget was $150 million and we still couldn’t pay our teachers enough to not want go to Ohio or Kentucky or Virginia,” he indicated. “To me, that’s unacceptable.”
So he asked himself what most people in his position eventually ask: What can I do that actually changes anything? He was already speaking professionally, consulting with nonprofits, and stepping into places where lived experience and clarity carried weight. But he wanted something bigger than speeches and incremental change.
“What if I started a business and found a real way to drive revenue that we could then invest in our region to solve the same social challenges I’ve been trying to solve for five years?” he said. “Mental health, suicide, addiction, recovery, lack of economic opportunity, poor health metrics, obesity, et cetera. How do we solve this holistic slew of social challenges in a simple and focused way through a business?”
The answer came in a way he didn’t expect. 
“God put it on my heart that we could do that through essentially selling ‘Free Hugs’ T-shirts,” he said. “But the movement is so much bigger than that.”
What emerged was #1BillionHugs — not an apparel line, but a human-scale intervention. 
“The endeavor came to mind as a way to promote this wearable symbol of hope,” Byers said. “To catalyze connection with individuals and, in that connected moment, to be a reason that people want to stay on this planet.”
He knows exactly what that moment can do. 
“I was wearing a Free Hugs T-shirt years ago, and I had wanted to take my life. I showed up at a Tudor’s Biscuit World to kind of self-medicate with food. And a woman behind the counter was jumping up and down pointing at her chest, and I realized she was motioning at the front of my shirt. So I said, ‘Come on out here.’ And she gave me a big-old hug. She said, ‘You don’t know how bad I needed that.’ And I told her I needed it too.”
He sat down afterward, still shaken, and another couple approached him. 
“They said, ‘We really appreciate you wearing that shirt.’ And I knew in that moment it was more than just a shirt. I was showing up imperfect, hadn’t shaved, hadn’t showered, had been in bed for a couple days — I knew that I was good enough to make a difference. And in that moment of connection, I didn’t want to take my life anymore.”
For Byers, that was the blueprint. 
“This isn’t like building an apparel brand,” he said. “This is a movement to get a billion people hugging more — to create a billion reasons to stay on this planet. Because if a billion people are engaged in connection, you’re going to have less suicide, improved mental health, improved psyche and rapport in your communities. You’re going to take better care of your physical health, have increased economic opportunities, increased collaboration.”
Whether at festivals, community centers, or chance encounters on the street, Byers uses one simple gesture to remind people they’re seen, valued, and not alone. (Courtesy photo)
Further proof
When Byers first imagined #1BillionHugs as an actual brand, the vision arrived all at once. 
“I thought, wow, you can count hugs essentially by people using the hashtag,” he said. “Which made me think about scale. What does that mean, a billion hugs? What would it take to get there? Maybe you have a hug counter. Maybe selling a billion shirts will also help you get there.”

His own willingness to learn became the driving force. 
“I also had to ask myself if I was willing to commit my life to it,” he said. “Was I willing to keep going until we get to a billion and this becomes my life’s work?” 
Ultimately, an injury forced him to slow down — and build. 
“I blew my knee out and I had to sit down,” he said. “Thankfully, having surgery allowed me to get to work on the website.”

A collection of different designers finally got the logo to his liking. The first shirt design emerged. 
“I was consulting with people in my network for six months.” 

The first pre-order was printed through Mountain Mindful at Coalfield Development, but Byers quickly realized he needed a different long-term partner. A chance meeting with a local pastor introduced him to a young Marshall student running his own print shop.
Soon after, the website launched in August. And the response was immediate. 
“We did 117 units in our four-week pre-order,” he added. “We had so much response from the press — a TV commercial, a segment on WSAZ, a couple different press publications. I spoke on a global mental wellness summit. Boys & Girls Club published our release. I got to speak at the West Virginia Goes Purple Fest. We’ve had so many hug ambassadors and people supporting the movement, and we’re not even three months in.”
Further proof, for Byers, that the need is real. 
“People are hungry for connection. People want to support organizations like the Boys & Girls Club and the Youth Leadership Association — where 10% of our proceeds go to.”
All the while, he knows that pace is the lesson. 
“Rome wasn’t built in a day. Nike did $6,000 in their first year. Twenty thousand in their second. I’m confident we’re going to do better than both of those numbers. But we don’t expect a billion in a year. I’ve learned to move at a sustainable pace versus all-or-nothing.”
Operationally, #1BillionHugs is obviously quite young, but the movement has already spread farther than Byers expected. “That first four-week pre-order went all over the nation,” he said. 

Most of the early response has come through online marketing and the Shopify store that feeds directly into the website. There, supporters can track their own hugs on the site’s counters, join a Facebook group where people share photos and stories, and contribute to a business page that is approaching its first thousand followers.
Byers has also assembled what he calls “hug hustlers” — brand ambassadors who help sell shirts, give hugs and spread the message. 
“We do accept applications for new hug hustlers,” he said. “We do want to engage with volunteers. We’re working on how that can be more formal and streamlined, because it’s mostly just me right now in terms of managing the operations.”
Byers speaks to students about mental health, recovery, and the power of showing up for one another—messages he once needed himself. (Courtesy photo)
A new story 
Byers is building the kind of partnerships he believes will ground the movement in communities. 
“I’ve met with nine pastors — trying to figure out how the message fits with churches,” he said — while simultaneously thinking carefully about how to involve schools in the future. “I’ve been hesitant to introduce it directly into schools so far, just because of the physical consent piece. You don’t want to spark anything that’s inappropriate, but you do want the kids to know that they’re loved, welcomed, and valued.”
The project donates 10% of its proceeds to charity partners — the Boys & Girls Club and the Youth Leadership Association — and Byers sent each a check recently.
“It’s $150 to each of those organizations — so $300 total we’ve donated just from August. It’s not a ton of money, but for me, as a person who came from tough circumstances, from the streets, no shoes, it means a lot. It shows me the vehicle that I was led to create, that people invested in, is producing fruit.”
As for explaining how #1BillionHugs fits into Appalachia, Byers doesn’t hesitate. 
“This state, region, all of it — we have our different social challenges, but there is a massive amount of social capital. Kindness.”
He’s seen it everywhere he goes. “It’s challenging for me to go anywhere in the state and not see somebody that I know,” he said — admitting that wearing the shirt opens new connections instantly — sometimes with people he didn’t realize he already shared community with. 
“Like the day I hugged a stranger who turned out to be the new director of the West Virginia Community Development Hub.”
Ultimately, Byers affirmed, Appalachia is where the idea emerged, and where the need feels most urgent. 
“My family has been plagued by mental illness and addiction,” he said. “I’ve lost a number of people who are very close to me — my brother, my mother, my best friend. Several of my classmates in high school to suicide and addiction. This place is where the idea met me and where its biggest and greatest impact will be carried out.”

Accordingly, he finds proof of concept wherever he goes. 
“People will share their stories, their personal connection to addiction, their personal connection to mental illness — to suicide,” he said. “I’m continuously amazed by what comes up when I just wear these shirts and live out the mission.” 
Among his greatest challenges at this point is a lack of personnel. 
“I’m extroverted by nature — and not having a fortified enough internal team or system to brainstorm and hash these ideas out has been tough,” he said. “And I can admit an occasional lack of emotional or mental fortitude in terms of being able to live out this dream optimally. But the greater point is that I continue showing up.”
For Byers, the future depends on him showing up. And when he pictures success five or 10 years down the road, it’s not about a number on a hug counter. 
“It goes beyond that,” he said. “I see the young people that look like I once did — on the west side of Charleston, or Parkersburg, or up in the hills of Preston County. The ones who need loving, caring, supportive adults. And because they might not have access to that, they’re ending up on the wrong path.”
Success, to him, is both simple and sophisticated. “It’s about being a presence in those areas and many more like them — seeing how all of the young people are supported and cared for. So they don’t have to go down the same path I did, which led to incarceration. So they don’t end up lonely, isolated or taking their lives like so many of my friends have.”
Byers describes #1BillionHugs as the front end of a comprehensive effort. 
“We get people hugging, we sell the merchandise, we create the revenue, and we invest that back into Appalachia,” he said. “If it works, the region becomes something people haven’t seen in generations. Appalachia becomes a beacon of hope. Where people want to move, want to stay, where people aren’t in despair, and where people are healing and healed and sharing that healing with others.”
To see that happen, to help build it, Byers said, “… is how I would define success.”

name: Idaho Capital Sun
title: With a thicker atmosphere and active volcanoes, was there ever a Yellowstone on Mars?
description: Today, Mars is a cold and dry planet with a very thin, low-pressure atmosphere. It has water, but it’s all frozen, locked up in underground ice (like permafrost) and in polar ice caps. But billions of years ago Mars had a thicker atmosphere and a warmer and wetter climate. It also used to have active volcanoes. So, with all […]
text:
Silica sinter (an amorphous form of silicon dioxide) forms from the waters that flow from hot springs near Shoshone Lake in Yellowstone National Park. (Photo courtesy of Jake Lowenstern/USGS)Today, Mars is a cold and dry planet with a very thin, low-pressure atmosphere. It has water, but it’s all frozen, locked up in underground ice (like permafrost) and in polar ice caps.
But billions of years ago Mars had a thicker atmosphere and a warmer and wetter climate. It also used to have active volcanoes. So, with all that heat, and all that water, is it possible that there were once hot springs on Mars? And how could we find out?
Mars has been a fascination for centuries, with early telescopic observations and fantastically speculative (and as it turns out, fictional) stories about possible canals and intelligent life forms. Modern Mars exploration began in the 1960s with spacecraft flybys, then in the following decades with orbiters, landers and finally robotic rovers.
There are currently seven active spacecraft orbiting Mars and two robotic “geologists” roving the surface, named Curiosity and Perseverance.
With all the images and data collected by these satellites and robotic explorers, we now have a good idea of what Mars is like on the surface.
There is no evidence for canals or complex lifeforms, but there is plenty of evidence for active surface processes, like wind, dust devils, migrating sand dunes and landslides. There is also evidence for past volcanism, such as large volcanoes and lava flows, and evidence for past flowing liquid water, such as river channels and delta deposits.
The evidence for past liquid water also includes a variety of hydrated minerals, hydrothermal alteration minerals, and silica deposits. It’s the silica deposits, discovered in 2007 by the Mars Exploration Rover, Spirit, that make you sit up and say, “Wow! Like in Yellowstone?”
Most of the silica deposits in Yellowstone are made of a white, lightweight, porous rock composed of opaline silica. The silica is dissolved from the rhyolitic volcanic rocks below and picked up by the hydrothermal fluids circulating underground.
When the hot, silica-rich fluids reach the surface, they cool down and precipitate layered silica deposits and mounds, called sinter, around geysers and hot springs.
There is also another way to get silica-rich deposits: acid-sulfate leaching. This is where sulfuric acid from volcanic gases reacts with the surrounding silicate rocks near the surface, leaching (removing) metal compounds, like iron and magnesium, and leaving a residue of opaline silica.
On Mars, silica deposits were found adjacent to a site dubbed Home Plate, within a large impact crater called Gusev crater, and there is evidence they formed from hydrothermal fluids. A key observation is the association of the silica deposits with volcanic activity.
The Home Plate feature represents the remains of volcanic ash deposits, which, along with nearby basaltic rocks, demonstrates that this place had magmatic activity capable of generating a hydrothermal system, although much smaller than the one that drives Yellowstone’s hot springs and fumaroles.
Because sinter deposits on Earth often host microbial life, they are a key target in the search for evidence of ancient microbial life on Mars. Excitingly, the silica deposits discovered by Spirit display tiny fingerlike structures that resemble features of Yellowstone sinter and other sinter deposits on Earth that are referred to as stromatolites, which form by a combination of biology and geology.
The colorful microbial communities that inhabit the edges and outflow channels of hot springs contribute to the growth of stromatolites along with the silica that precipitates from the water. The fingerlike structures observed by Spirit are made of silica, but they have not been shown to include organic matter and may not be equivalent to hot spring stromatolites on Earth.
At this point, they are assumed to have formed from geologic processes alone.
Hydrothermal deposits on Mars. (A) This image was acquired by the Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter’s High Resolution Imaging Science Experiment camera on Nov. 22, 2006. It shows a bright plateau of layered rocks about 90 meters (98 yards) across called, “Home Plate.” NASA image: PSP_001513_1655_red; Image Credit: NASA/JPL-Caltech/Univ. of Arizona. “x” marks the locations of the rover images in B and C. (B) This approximately true-color image was acquired by the panchromatic camera on NASA’s Mars Exploration Rover, Spirit, on May 6, 2007. It shows a patch of bright, silica-rich soil that was exposed when Spirit drove over it. The track of disturbed soil is about 20 centimeters (8 inches) wide. NASA Image: PIA09491; Image Credit: NASA/JPL/Cornell. (C) This approximately true-color image was acquired by the panchromatic camera on NASA’s Mars Exploration Rover, Spirit, on March 13, 2006. It is about 1 meter across at the base. It shows the nodular morphology of opaline silica outcrops adjacent to Home Plate. Image modified from Ruff et al., 2020 (https://doi.org/10.1089/ast.2019.2044).
Still, understanding microorganisms that inhabit Yellowstone’s hot springs, and the evidence they leave behind, could help answer some fundamental questions in the field of astrobiology: Is there, or has there ever been, life elsewhere in the solar system?
Going beyond Mars, there is also evidence of geyser activity on some of the icy moons in the outer solar system, such as Neptune’s moon, Triton, and Saturn’s moon, Enceladus. Jupiter’s moon, Europa, is another outer solar system body that has a liquid water ocean underneath its crust of water ice and may host geysers that are spurting out samples of this water.
In October 2024, NASA launched the Europa Clipper mission to investigate. It will arrive in 2030. Stay tuned.
Yellowstone is not just a natural laboratory for Earth science studies. With its history of caldera-forming volcanism, geothermal activity, geysers, hydrothermal mineral deposits, and thermophilic bacteria, it is also an excellent laboratory for exciting planetary science research.



For more about hot spring deposits on Mars, see the following publication: Ruff, S.W., Campbell, K.A., Van Kranendonk, M.J., Rice, M.S. and Farmer, J.D., 2020. The case for ancient hot springs in Gusev crater, Mars. Astrobiology, 20(4), p.475–499, https://doi.org/10.1089/ast.2019.2044.
